verses.text: After two full years, Pharaoh had a dream: he was standing by the Nile.
verses.comment: Joseph's time of waiting corresponds to trusting God even in delay. Like other prophetic dreams in scripture, Pharaoh's dreams foreshadow God's providence for His people.

verses.text: Suddenly, out of the Nile came seven cows, sleek and fat, and they grazed among the reeds.
verses.comment: The Nile is Egypt's lifeblood; its imagery emphasizes the scope of what God is about to do for the nation through Joseph.

verses.text: After them, seven other cows came up out of the Nile, ugly and thin, and stood beside the other cows on the riverbank.
verses.comment: The striking contrast shows the dramatic change that is about to happen—a motif common in biblical prophecy.

verses.text: The ugly, thin cows ate up the seven sleek, fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
verses.comment: The swallowing of the fat cows by the thin prefigures the years of famine that will devour the years of plenty, as will also be revealed in the interpretation.

verses.text: He fell asleep again and dreamed a second time: seven ears of grain, healthy and good, grew on a single stalk.
verses.comment: Dreams in pairs are often signs in Scripture that God has firmly decided a matter and will bring it to pass swiftly (cf. Gen. 41:32).

verses.text: After them, seven ears, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprouted up.
verses.comment: Famine symbolized by thin, scorched grain links Egypt’s fate to the direction eastern winds, often bringing drought.

verses.text: The thin ears swallowed up the seven healthy, full ears. Then Pharaoh woke up—it was a dream.
verses.comment: Repetition highlights certainty; see Gen. 41:32. Destruction of the good by the bad is a recurring biblical theme, ultimately reversed in Christ’s victory.

verses.text: In the morning, his mind was troubled, so he sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them for him.
verses.comment: Earthly wisdom alone cannot reveal divine mysteries—a pattern fulfilled when Christ is recognized as Wisdom itself (cf. 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, 'Today I remember my offenses.'
verses.comment: Divine providence works through the memory of the cupbearer, showing that human timing and God’s timing may differ, but God’s purpose prevails.

verses.text: 'When Pharaoh was angry with his servants, he put me and the chief baker in the custody of the captain of the guard.'
verses.comment: The reference back to Joseph’s earlier prophecy serves the narrative and proves Joseph as a faithful and true interpreter.

verses.text: 'We both had dreams on the same night, he and I. Each dream had its own interpretation.'
verses.comment: Each dream having its own interpretation points to the specificity of God’s revelation, similar to the unique prophetic messages given throughout Scripture.

verses.text: 'There was a young Hebrew with us, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted them for us, giving each man its own interpretation.'
verses.comment: Joseph, the outsider and servant, prefigures Christ, who came as a servant (Phil. 2:7) to bring true interpretation and salvation.

verses.text: 'Just as he interpreted for us, so it happened: I was restored to my position, and the other man was hanged.'
verses.comment: The fulfillment of Joseph’s words confirms his gift as authentic—a mark of a true prophet, which is foundational in the understanding of biblical authority.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent and called Joseph, and they quickly brought him out of the pit. After shaving and changing his clothes, he came in before Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Joseph’s transition from prison to court echoes Christ’s resurrection, ascent, and glorification after humiliation (cf. Phil. 2:8-9).

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I have had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. But I have heard it said of you that you can understand a dream to interpret it.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s reputation was earned by faithfulness, as is the Christian call—proven character in servitude leads to elevation in God’s time.

verses.text: Joseph answered Pharaoh, 'It is not in me; God will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.'
verses.comment: Joseph credits God as the true source of wisdom. The necessity of divine revelation is a recurring biblical affirmation (James 1:5).

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile.'
verses.comment: Pharaoh initiates the recounting; the emphasis is placed on the Nile, the source of life and sustenance in Egypt.

verses.text: 'Out of the Nile came seven cows, fat and sleek, and they grazed among the reeds.'
verses.comment: This verse formally repeats the vision, underscoring its importance.

verses.text: 'Then seven other cows came up after them, miserable and very ugly and thin. I have never seen such poor cows in all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Pharaoh adds his personal judgment (“never seen”) to highlight the severity of the forthcoming famine.

verses.text: 'The thin, ugly cows ate up the first seven fat cows,'
verses.comment: Restates the symbolic act—evil overtaking the good, as seen throughout the history of God’s people, but never ultimately triumphant.

verses.text: 'Yet when they had eaten them, no one could tell they had done so; they looked just as bad as before. Then I woke up.'
verses.comment: Famine will be so severe it will erase any memory of the abundance.

verses.text: 'In my dream I also saw seven ears, full and good, growing on a single stalk.'
verses.comment: Continuing the repetition for emphasis, corresponding to the earlier vision.

verses.text: 'Then seven ears, withered, thin, and scorched by the east wind, grew up after them.'
verses.comment: The East Wind, often a sign of judgment in the Old Testament (see Ex. 10:13; Hos. 13:15).

verses.text: 'And the thin ears swallowed up the seven good ears. I told this to the magicians, but no one could explain it to me.'
verses.comment: Human wisdom is insufficient against divine mysteries. Only God’s chosen can rightly interpret His will.

verses.text: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, 'The dreams of Pharaoh are one; God has revealed to Pharaoh what He is about to do.'
verses.comment: Joseph acts as the divine mediator, prefiguring Christ’s role as mediator between God and man (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: 'The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years; it is one dream.'
verses.comment: Divine patterns in Scripture often have both literal and symbolic fulfillment, illustrating God’s unity of action.

verses.text: 'The seven thin, ugly cows which came up after them are seven years, and also the seven empty ears scorched by the east wind. They are seven years of famine.'
verses.comment: Parallel symbolism strengthens the certainty and clarity of God’s communication, as seen in Christ’s teaching style.

verses.text: 'It is as I have spoken to Pharaoh. God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.'
verses.comment: Divine revelation underscores that God remains sovereign over history, showing mercy by warning in advance.

verses.text: 'See, seven years of great abundance are coming throughout all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Prophetic warning for repentance and preparation—a theme often repeated through the prophetic books.

verses.text: 'But after them will arise seven years of famine, and all the abundance will be forgotten in the land of Egypt. The famine will consume the land.'
verses.comment: Coming famine illustrates the peril of material reliance without spiritual preparedness.

verses.text: 'The plenty in the land will not be remembered, because the famine that follows will be so severe.'
verses.comment: Temporal blessings are fleeting, a call to treasure what lasts—God’s word and faith.

verses.text: 'The matter was doubled to Pharaoh because the thing is established by God, and God will quickly bring it to pass.'
verses.comment: Certainty of God’s decree—doubled dreams mean God has fixed it. See spiritual typology: God’s promises and judgments are sure.

verses.text: 'Now, therefore, let Pharaoh select a discerning and wise man, and set him over the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s suggestion introduces godly stewardship, foreshadowing the role of spiritual leaders set by God for the common good.

verses.text: 'Let Pharaoh do this, and let him appoint overseers over the land, to collect one-fifth of the produce of the land of Egypt during the seven plentiful years.'
verses.comment: One-fifth as a tithe-like share; orderly administration and offering for the good of all.

verses.text: 'Let them gather all the food of these good years that are coming, and store up grain under the authority of Pharaoh to keep as food in the cities.'
verses.comment: Centralized storage of grain under authority prefigures the later common storehouse of blessings under godly leadership.

verses.text: 'This food shall be a reserve for the land against the seven years of famine that are to come on the land of Egypt, so that the land may not perish during the famine.'
verses.comment: God’s provision through wise administration; a model for physical and spiritual preparedness.

verses.text: The advice seemed good to Pharaoh and to all his servants.
verses.comment: Even pagan rulers can recognize the wisdom of God when it is manifest; God’s truth is powerful and persuasive.

verses.text: Pharaoh said to his servants, 'Can we find a man like this, in whom is the spirit of God?'
verses.comment: The pagan king unconsciously recognizes the working of God’s Spirit in Joseph—a type of the Spirit’s work in believers, and the anointing of grace upon God’s chosen leaders.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'Since God has shown you all this, there is no one as discerning and wise as you.'
verses.comment: Joseph is publicly acknowledged for his divinely-given wisdom—a foreshadowing of Christ, Wisdom incarnate (see Col. 2:3).

verses.text: 'You shall be over my house, and all my people shall order themselves as you command. Only with regard to the throne will I be greater than you.'
verses.comment: Joseph is exalted, second only to Pharaoh, signifying the unique primacy given to God’s chosen. Christ is exalted at the right hand of the Father (Acts 2:33).

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'See, I have set you over all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Formal installation marks Joseph’s new authority—prefiguring the assignation of spiritual authority in the Church.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his hand and put it on Joseph's hand, clothed him in linen garments, and put a gold chain around his neck.
verses.comment: The giving of garments and signet signifies full investiture—symbolic of sanctification and authority in God’s plan (Rev. 3:5).

verses.text: He made him ride in his second chariot, and they cried out before him, 'Bow the knee!' Thus he set him over all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Public proclamation of Joseph’s authority prefigures Christ’s exaltation (Phil. 2:10: ‘At the name of Jesus every knee should bow’).

verses.text: Moreover, Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I am Pharaoh, and without your permission no one shall raise hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Joseph receives complete practical authority; mirrors biblical principles of delegated authority under God.

verses.text: Pharaoh called Joseph's name Zaphenath-paneah, and gave him in marriage to Asenath, daughter of Potiphera priest of On. Thus, Joseph went out over the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph’s new name and marriage symbolizes his integration into Egyptian high society, yet he remains faithful to God. Typologically, the union with a Gentile bride prefigures the inclusion of all nations into God’s people (see Eph. 3:6).

verses.text: Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. Joseph went out from Pharaoh's presence and traveled through all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph’s age (thirty) recalls the age of priestly service and Christ beginning His ministry at thirty, marking a scriptural pattern for leadership.

verses.text: During the seven years of plenty, the land produced abundantly.
verses.comment: God’s prediction fulfilled; His word does not fail.

verses.text: He gathered all the food of the seven years in the land of Egypt and stored the food in the cities, placing in each city the food from the fields surrounding it.
verses.comment: Orderly provision and prudence again serve as a biblical model for wise stewardship of resources.

verses.text: Joseph stored up grain in great abundance, like the sand of the sea, until he stopped measuring it, for it could not be measured.
verses.comment: The phrase ‘like the sand of the sea’ recalls God’s promises to Abraham—abundance as blessing.

verses.text: Before the year of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
verses.comment: Joseph’s sons born in Egypt signify God’s blessing amidst exile, illustrating hope and fruitfulness even in a foreign land.

verses.text: Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh, 'For,' he said, 'God has made me forget all my hardship and all my father's house.'
verses.comment: ‘Manasseh’ means ‘causing to forget’—God grants restoration beyond suffering. Reminiscent of the transformed Christian life when one is made new in Christ.

verses.text: The second he named Ephraim, 'For God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.'
verses.comment: ‘Ephraim’ means ‘fruitful’—reminding believers that God can bring a rich harvest out of tribulation. Cf. Rom. 8:28.

verses.text: The seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt came to an end.
verses.comment: All earthly abundance is temporary—a subtle call to eternal hope founded in faith.

verses.text: The seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in all lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
verses.comment: God’s word is proved true; Egypt as the source of bread in a crisis foreshadows spiritual feeding for the whole world.

verses.text: When all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread, and Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, 'Go to Joseph; what he says to you, do.'
verses.comment: Joseph is mediator and dispenser of life’s necessities, pointing to Christ, who is the true Bread from Heaven (John 6:35). The phrase ‘Do whatever he tells you’ echoes Mary’s words at Cana.

verses.text: So when the famine had spread over all the land, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe in the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph’s stewardship saved many. This act anticipates the opening of Christ’s own storehouses of grace for the world.

verses.text: Moreover, all the earth came to Egypt to Joseph to buy grain, because the famine was severe over all the earth.
verses.comment: ‘All the earth’ coming to Joseph prefigures all nations coming to one source for salvation and life. Joseph here is a type of Christ, the world’s true Redeemer (cf. Matt. 28:19).
